metadata.case_name: Babubhai Dullabhbhai Bhandari v. District Magistrate of Thana & Ors. and Kunwar Rameshwar Singh v. Deputy Commissioner of Police & Ors.

facts.text: Petitioner in Petition No. 439, Babubhai Dullabhbhai Bhandari, is a citizen of India carrying on trade in grass at Bhilad, railway station on Western Railway.

On 21st January 1955, Deputy Superintendent of Police and Sub-Divisional Police Officer, Bhiwandi Division, served notice under section 56 of Bombay Police Act, 1951 on petitioner Babubhai, proposing removal outside District of Thana for two years due to activities causing alarm: dealing in smuggled foreign liquor, criminal intimidation, assaults on villagers and officials, possession of unlicensed firearms.
Petitioner Babubhai appeared before police officer on 27th January 1955 and on subsequent dates, examined seven respectable persons as witnesses.

On 11th July 1955, District Magistrate of Thana passed order externing Babubhai outside Thana District, satisfied he engages in threats, assaults on officials and residents, illicit liquor traffic, witnesses unwilling to come forward due to apprehension.
Babubhai's appeal to Government dismissed on 9th September 1955.
Babubhai's petition under Article 226 to Bombay High Court dismissed in limine on 7th November 1955.

District Magistrate's affidavit states order passed after perusing police reports, petitioner's explanation, witnesses; material clear, not vague; names not disclosed as witnesses unwilling; activities cause alarm to public and officials; petitioner discharged earlier as witnesses feared him.
Petitioner in Petition No. 440, Kunwar Rameshwar Singh, citizen of India, social worker improving lot of prostitutes and singing girls in Bombay.

On 2nd November 1954, notice under section 56 read with 59 served on Kunwar alleging since October 1953, movements causing alarm in Falkland Road etc.: extorting money from prostitutes, singing girls, shopkeepers by threats, assaults; posting associates to prevent customers; damaging property; witnesses unwilling.
On 4th January 1955, Deputy Commissioner of Police passed externment order directing Kunwar to remove from Greater Bombay within 7 days, not enter for 2 years without permission.
Kunwar's appeal to State of Bombay dismissed on 17th January 1955.
Kunwar's Article 226 petition to Bombay High Court dismissed on 14th March 1955; Letters Patent Appeal dismissed holding court cannot go behind officer's opinion on witnesses.

Kunwar entered Greater Bombay on 6th April 1955 due to arrest warrant in pending case, arrested for breach of externment; convicted under s.142, sentenced 9 months RI on 8th September 1955; appeal to High Court dismissed 5th October 1955; special leave petition to SC dismissed 21st November 1955.
Respondent's affidavit on Kunwar: background from UP, failed jobs, false representations for accommodation/shops, convicted; activities in redlight district with bad associates extorting by violence.
Petitions heard with Petition No. 272 of 1955 under s.57.

legal_issues.text: Constitutionality of section 56 of Bombay Police Act, 1951, particularly whether it violates Article 19, and validity of externment orders passed thereunder.
Whether opportunity under s.59 was given; whether particulars of evidence supplied; interpretation of 'witnesses unwilling to come forward' including police/customs officers.
Whether section applies only if all witnesses unwilling, or excludes police/customs officers.

petitioner_arguments.text: No opportunity under s.59 as particulars of evidence and activities not given.
Section 56 requires all witnesses unwilling; police/customs officers must come forward.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Gurbachan Singh v. State of Bombay

petitioner_arguments.text: Entered Bombay due to arrest warrant, testing validity.

respondent_arguments.text: Orders passed after police reports, explanation, hearing; material clear, witnesses unwilling including public, police, customs due to fear; activities cause alarm.
Petitioner should have obtained permission before returning.

court_reasoning.text: Section 56 constitutional, following Gurbachan Singh v. State of Bombay upholding similar s.27 of old Act; two conditions: (a) movements causing alarm or reasonable belief in offences, (b) witnesses unwilling due to apprehension.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Officer satisfied on both conditions may pass order after opportunity under s.59.

court_reasoning.text: Gurbachan Singh does not require all witnesses unwilling; not limited to non-police witnesses; police/customs need not always brave danger.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Words of s.56 do not support extreme contention.

court_reasoning.text: Opportunity given; general nature of allegations supplied; Kunwar's conviction final.

holdings.text: Section 56 of Bombay Police Act, 1951 is constitutional and orders valid.
'Witnesses unwilling' does not require all witnesses or exclude police/customs officers.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gurbachan Singh v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Upholds constitutionality of similar provision (s.27 City Police Act 1902); interprets 'witnesses unwilling'

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Police Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Challenged provisions for externment; opportunity to show cause; breach punishable.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petitions under 32 for fundamental rights; prior proceedings under 226; alleged violation of 19.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences involving force/violence or specified chapters trigger s.56(b).

outcome.summary: Petitions under Article 32 challenging constitutionality of s.56 Bombay Police Act and externment orders dismissed; section held constitutional following Gurbachan Singh; orders valid.

key_quotes.text: Whenever it shall appear... that the movements or acts of any person are causing or calculated to cause alarm, danger or harm to person or property... and when in the opinion of such officer witnesses are not willing to come forward to give evidence in public against such person...
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s.56 defining conditions for externment.

key_quotes.text: The law is certainly an extraordinary one and has been made only to meet those exceptional cases where no witnesses for fear of violence... are willing to depose publicly against certain bad characters.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Gurbachan Singh, context for 'witnesses unwilling'.

key_quotes.text: Section 56 of the Act is not unconstitutional and that the orders passed against the petitioners are not invalid.
key_quotes.speaker: court
